Expectation1: Complete assigned tasks by the agreed deadlines
Situation1: The task feeds directly into the next teammate’s work and delays would ripple.
Situation2: They notice a few pool chairs are slightly misaligned but still usable.
Story:
I sat at my desk, eyes flicking between the spreadsheet on my screen and the clock on the wall. The deadline for my part of the project was looming, and I knew that if I didn’t finish by noon, the next person in the chain would be stuck waiting, their own work delayed. My phone buzzed with a reminder: “Check pool area for safety.” As the designated lifeguard for the morning, I was also responsible for making sure everything around the pool was in order. I glanced out the window and noticed a few pool chairs were out of line—nothing dangerous, but not up to standard either.

My colleague’s voice echoed in my mind, “Please don’t hold us up, I need your numbers to finish my section.” At the same time, I remembered the supervisor’s words: “We expect the pool area to be tidy and safe at all times.” I felt the pressure building inside me, torn between the urgent need to finish my work and the responsibility to maintain the pool. My hands hovered over the keyboard, heart pounding, as I wrestled with which role to prioritize.
